IMPORTANT  
Home and Pro editions of Windows 11, version 22H2 will reach end of service on October 8, 2024. Until then, these editions will only receive security updates. They will not receive non-security, preview updates. To continue receiving security and non-security updates after October 8, 2024, we recommend that you update to the latest version of Windows. 
Note  
We will continue to support Enterprise and Education editions after October 8, 2024.

. For an overview of Windows 11, version 23H2, see its

.

This update addresses security issues for your Windows operating system. 
Improvements

Windows 11, version 23H2 
Important:  
Use EKB  
KB5027397 
 to update to Windows 11, version 23H2. 
This security update includes quality improvements. Key changes include: 
This build includes all the improvements in Windows 11, version 22H2. 
No additional issues are documented for this release. 
Windows 11, version 22H2 
This security update includes improvements that were a part of update  
KB5040527 
(released July 23, 2024). Below is a summary of the key issues that this update addresses when you install this KB. If there are new features, it lists them as well. The bold text within the brackets indicates the item or area of the change we are documenting. 
[BitLocker (known issue)] 
 A  
BitLocker recovery 
 screen shows when you start up your device. This occurs after you install the July 9, 2024, update. This issue is more likely to occur if  
device encryption 
 is on. Go to  
Settings 
 >  
Privacy & Security 
 >  
Device encryption 
. To unlock your drive, Windows might ask you to enter the recovery key from your Microsoft account. 
[Lock screen] 
 This update addresses CVE-2024-38143. Because of this, the “Use my windows user account” check box is not available on the lock screen to connect to Wi-Fi. 
[NetJoinLegacyAccountReuse] 
 This update removes this registry key. For more information refer to  
KB5020276—Netjoin: Domain join hardening changes 
. 
[Secure Boot Advanced Targeting (SBAT) and Linux Extensible Firmware Interface (EFI)]  
This update applies SBAT to systems that run Windows. This stops vulnerable Linux EFI (Shim bootloaders) from running. This SBAT update will not apply to systems that dual-boot Windows and Linux. After the SBAT update is applied, older Linux ISO images might not boot. If this occurs, work with your Linux vendor to get an updated ISO image. 
If you installed earlier updates, only the new updates contained in this package will be downloaded and installed on your device. 
For more information about security vulnerabilities, please refer to the  
Security Update Guide 
 website and the  
August 2024 Security Updates 
. 
Windows 11 servicing stack update (KB5041584) - 22621.4027 and 22631.4027 
This update makes quality improvements to the servicing stack, which is the component that installs Windows updates. Servicing stack updates (SSU) ensure that you have a robust and reliable servicing stack so that your devices can receive and install Microsoft updates. 
Known issues in this update 
Microsoft is not currently aware of any issues with this update.

summary:
KB5041585 is a critical security update released on August 13, 2024, for Windows 11 version 22H2 (OS Builds 22621.4037) and version 23H2 (OS Builds 22631.4037). This update addresses high-impact vulnerabilities including CVE-2024-38143 related to the lock screen Wi-Fi connectivity and issues with Secure Boot Advanced Targeting (SBAT) that may prevent older Linux ISO images from booting. Important updates to BitLocker recovery prompts post-July 2024 updates are also included. Installation of this update can be performed through Windows Update, WSUS, or the Microsoft Update Catalog, with no special prerequisites noted beyond ensuring the servicing stack update (SSU) is integrated.

**Technical Breakdown**

**Vulnerabilities and Exploits**:
- This update addresses high-impact vulnerabilities, including:
  - **CVE-2024-38143**: Related to lock screen Wi-Fi connectivity failures.
  - **Secure Boot Advanced Targeting (SBAT)**: Prevents vulnerable Linux EFI (Shim bootloaders) from executing on Windows systems, potentially impacting dual-boot configurations.

**Workarounds and Known Issues**:
- BitLocker Recovery Prompt:
  - Trigger: Device encryption enabled after installing the July 9, 2024 update.
  - Resolution: Recovery key may be required; obtain it from your Microsoft account.
- Lock Screen Connectivity Issue:
  - Impact: No access to Wi-Fi via the lock screen.
  - Resolution: Requires security patch KB5041585.
- Secure Boot Issue:
  - Impact: Older Linux ISO images may fail to boot.
  - Resolution: Contact your Linux vendor for updated images.

**Installation Process and Prerequisites**:
- To install this update:
  - Use Windows Update, Windows Update for Business, or WSUS configured with:
    ```
    [WSUS Configuration]
    Product: Windows 11
    Classification: Security Updates
    ```
  - Ensure that the latest servicing stack update (KB5041584) is installed prior to applying this cumulative update.

- To uninstall the LCU:
  ```
  [Powershell]
  ```powershell
  DISM /online /get-packages
  DISM /Remove-Package /packagename:<LCU Package Name>
  ```
  Note: Do not use `wusa.exe` for uninstallation as it will not work on the combined update package containing the SSU. 

This update reinforces security measures for Windows 11 while delivering essential quality improvements necessary for system integrity, especially in enterprise environments.
